div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 70876] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 8, 1907. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athena), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with the Oriental Railways Express Service for VIENNA, BERLIN, PARIS, & London.
S.S. Osmanieh Wednesday 4p.m. July 17,31, August 14 and 28
S.S. Ismallia Wednesday 4p.m. July 10,24, August 7 and 21

PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE-The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alter- nately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caifta (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina calling fortnightly at Larnaca (Cyprus) and ctoninuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli and Constantinople.

SUDAN - DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.-The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednes- days at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.-Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden
For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez or to THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIKA REISE-BUREAU

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Service fortnightly from HAMBURG; weekly from ANTWERP; every 4 weeks from BORDEAUX direct to ALEXANDRIA; homewards every 2 weeks from ALEXANDRIA for ROTTERDAM and HAMBURG. Goods forwarded at through-rates from all German Railway Stations on direct Bills of Lading to ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, SYRIA, etc.
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Chios July 6 from Antwerp.
S.S. Athos July 9 from Hamburg.
S.S. Andros July 21 from Hamburg.
S.S. Hainsut now in port discharging bound for Rotterdam and Hamburg
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

S.S. MANDALAY 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about 22nd July for Malta, Marseilles & Devon.

Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL in 13 days.

div.head: BANQUE DU CAIRE, LIMITED,
div.p: CAIRO.
CAPITAL: Lstg. 600,000.

The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities, current accounts opened. Receives money on deposit at sight at 3% per annum.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.

div.head: Service Maritime Roumain
div.p: 16 Rue Sevostria 16

Par suite de la qearstaine de 48 houres impoede par la Turquis aux provenances d'Egypte les paquebots poute du Service Maritime Roumain quitteront Alexandria chaque quinzaine le Mercredi 4 heures de Papres raddi. Au cette quarantalae serait reduite a 24 heures seulement les departa auront lieu le Jeudi a 4 p.m.
For particulars apply to the Agents: OTTO STERZINC, Opera Square, CAIRO. W. H. MULLER & Co., ALEXANDRIA
THOS. COOK & Bon (Egypt) Ltd., are authorized to sell tickets in CAIRO and ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice Trieste. Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria Saturdays 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi Tuesdays 5 a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice Wednesday about 9.30 a.m. Passengers may proceed from Venice to Switzerland, Paris and London by the 2 p.m. and 11.5 p.m. – Expresses. Arrival at Trieste Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe proceeding the same evening to Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussel, Ostende and London. Arrival at London every Friday 5.12 p.m.
Special Train Service from Cairo Station to Alexandria Quay alongside steamer, Saturdays at 9.30 a.m.
Steamer leaves Alexandria every Thursday 10 a.m. On and from April 11th at 4 p.m.
Syrian-Caramanian Line. Port Said, Jaffa, Beyrout, Tripoli, Alexandretta, Mersina, Febr. 18; March 4, 18 ; April 1. 15, 29 ; May 13, 27 ; June 10, 24.
Syrian-Cyprus Line. Beyrout, Limassol, Larnaca, Mersina, Febr. 26; March 12, 26 ; April 9. 23 ; May 7, 21 ; June 4, 18.
Far East Lines. Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama and Kobé, 6 March, 3 April, 4 May, 3 June.
To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service 22 Febr.; 7, 23 March ; 4, 23 April ; 8 May ; 8 June.

To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about 18 Jan., 18 Feb., 18 March, 18 April, 18 May, 18 June. – For information apply to the Agents, Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, and Khartum.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER
ESTABLISHED 1880
Editor and Manager - - R. SHELLING.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
MONDAY, JULY 8, 1907.
THE LORDS DEBATE
Here are some of the comments of the Press on the resolution against the Lords.

“The Government plan is simple, and certainly if it errs at all," says the "Daily News,” does not err on the side of too drastic treatment of the hereditary chamber. Any- thing less would mean the frank acceptance of the subordination of the elected House; a uni-cameral system when the Tories are in power; Liberalism and progress in a condition of permanent enslavement and impotence." Every argument which the Opposition put for- ward in favour of a Second Chamber "is an argument against the House of Lords" "It is an obviously effective, though undoubtedly a rather cumbrous, plan, and a good many people will be inclined to think with Mr. Shackleton that one of the offers to the Lords might be lopped from it,” says the ‘Tribune," which also declares that the scheme “represents the irreducible minimum of reform.” "The proposal is one of great moderation, while yet, within the limits," says the “Daily Chronicle,” "of real efficacy. To attempt anything less would be to acquiesce in pretensions fatal alike to the rights and liberties of the Commons, and to the possibility of serious Liberal reform.” In the opinion of the “Morning Leader," which declares that “Democracy has come to grips with privilege,” the plan “is in a very high degree satisfactory." "If,” says the "West- minster Gazette,” “the Tory Party are really sincere in acknowledging that the will of the country must prevail, they have here a scheme which effects the object without disturbing the constitution of the House of Lords.”

Feeling sure after reading his speech that Mr. Balfour must have “had his tongue in his cheek,” and regretting the Premier's attitude against the Referendum, the “Manchester Guardian” says: —“It is not sufficient to pro- nounce the Government's scheme bad; it is necessary to find a better." The "Guardian" notes with approval Lord Robert Cecil's ad- mission that “the existing system operates one-sidedly." The surprising feature of the debate, says the "Liverpool Post,” is “the absence of any substantial arguments against the proposals of the Prime Minister." The Opposition, declare* the ‘Sooth Wales Daily News,” "have a miserable oase to defend, and Mr. Balfour defended it miserably.” "The date of the next General Election," says the “Leeds Mercury,” “may be accurately fore- casted when the date for the introduction of the Lords’ Veto Bill is known.”

"Seldom, if ever,” declares the ‘Times,” has a change of such moment been urged in a speech displaying so little sense of responsi- bility, or based upon such flimsy grounds" Sir Henry seems to be returning to the obsolete theory that the House of Commons—meaning in practice any chance majority of the House of Commons—is the true Sovereign, and not the nation. The only reason which the Prime Minister could assign for his proposal was the party complexion of the House of Lords, which makes it passive under a Unionist Government, and active only when the Liberals are in power. Now, even if we assume this contention to be true, it is worth noting, as Liberals have noted, that the Government plan is a very imperfect remedy.”

"The devil can quote Scripture when it suits his ends, and Sir Henry Campbell- Bannerman, excellent man, will talk Consti- tutionalism when he wishes to bring about Revolution,” says the “Standard” "Two courses are open: either to strengthen the House of Lords by restoring its character as an assembly selected on grounds of spe- cial competence for the work to be done or to weaken it by diminishing its powers. Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman has chosen the second and as it seems to us, the less judicious and less promising course," says the "Morning Post" "To the crude formula that, the Commons shall prevail," says the “Daily Telegraph" “the unanswerable Union- ist retort is that the country shall prevail, and that the Peers shall prevail with it whenever they are shown to be, as in 1893 and now, the true interpreters of national opinion.”

“Mr. Morley, reflecting on Mr Gladstone’s Parliamentary vicissitudes, quoted with appre- ciation the saying by Sorel that politics are a game of chance They would become a game of great national peril," says the "Scotsman,” if the counsels of the present Prime Minister were accepted"

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement
div.p: OF THE
"Egyptian Gazette."

The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaust- ive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton need, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt- for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."
